title: 106_s994
content: The Act may be cited as the "Juvenile Misuse of Firearms Prevention Act". It includes penalties for unlawful acts by juveniles related to restricting access to certain firearms. The "Juvenile Misuse of Firearms Prevention Act" amends Section 924(a) of title 18, United States Code, to impose penalties on juveniles who violate section 922(x), including fines, imprisonment up to 1 year, or probation with conditions for possession of a handgun or ammunition. A juvenile can be charged for possessing a handgun, ammunition, or a semiautomatic assault weapon in violation of section 922(x)(2) and may face fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both if convicted. A juvenile charged with possessing a handgun, ammunition, or a semiautomatic assault weapon in violation of section 922(x)(2) may face fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both if convicted. Additionally, a person other than a juvenile who knowingly violates section 922(x) shall be fined and imprisoned. A violation of section 922(x) involving selling or transferring a handgun, ammunition, or semiautomatic assault weapon to a juvenile for use in a violent felony can result in fines, imprisonment up to 20 years, or both. The term 'violent felony' is defined in section 924(e)(2)(B) of this title. In cases where a juvenile is prosecuted in a US district court and subject to certain penalties, they will be treated under the same laws and sentencing procedures as an adult. Juveniles sentenced to imprisonment will not be released at age 18. Additionally, it is unlawful to sell or transfer firearms to juveniles under section 922(x) of title 18, US Code. It is illegal to sell or transfer firearms to juveniles under section 922(x) of title 18, US Code. Juveniles are prohibited from possessing handguns, ammunition suitable for handguns, and semiautomatic assault weapons unless temporarily transferred for use. Juveniles are prohibited from possessing assault weapons unless used for specific purposes such as employment, ranching, target practice, hunting, or firearm instruction. Juveniles can possess handguns, ammunition, or semiautomatic assault weapons if they have written consent from a parent or guardian not prohibited from owning firearms. Juveniles can possess handguns, ammunition, or semiautomatic assault weapons with written consent from a parent or guardian. During transportation, the firearm must be unloaded and in a locked container. For ranching or farming activities, a juvenile may possess and use a handgun. Juveniles can possess handguns, ammunition, or semiautomatic assault weapons with written consent from a parent or guardian, as long as the adult directing ranching or farming activities approves. Members of the Armed Forces or National Guard can possess these weapons in the line of duty, and inheritance of title is allowed for juveniles. Juveniles can possess handguns, ammunition, or semiautomatic assault weapons with written consent from a parent or guardian. The possession of such weapons can be transferred to a juvenile in defense of themselves or others in the residence. If the juvenile's possession of the weapon becomes unlawful due to their actions, it will not be permanently confiscated by the Government. The term 'juvenile' refers to a person under 18 years of age. In a prosecution involving a juvenile defendant under 18 years of age, the court must require the presence of the parent or legal guardian at all proceedings. The court has the authority to enforce this requirement using contempt power and may excuse the parent or guardian's attendance for valid reasons. The Act and its amendments will become effective 180 days after enactment. The penalties for using a firearm to wound, injure, or maim another person have been increased under the amended Section 924 of title 18, United States Code. The minimum term of imprisonment for this offense is now 15 years. Additionally, Section 924(h) has been amended to impose a minimum 5-year term of imprisonment for certain offenses. These changes will take effect 180 days after the enactment of the Act. TITLE IV--PROVIDING STATES WITH INCENTIVES TO PROSECUTE JUVENILES AS ADULTS FOR SPECIFIC FIREARM OFFENSES Title IV provides incentives for states to prosecute juveniles as adults for specific firearm offenses. States must have laws, policies, or programs in place to prosecute juveniles aged 14 or older as adults in criminal court if they used a firearm during offenses like murder, robbery with a weapon, assault with a weapon, or forcible rape. Juveniles aged 14 or older can be prosecuted as adults for specific firearm offenses, including murder, robbery with a weapon, assault with a weapon, forcible rape, or serious drug offenses.
